documents.title: Arithmetic Mean - Geometric Mean Inequality (AM-GM)
documents.text: The AM-GM inequality states that for non-negative real numbers, the arithmetic mean is always greater than or equal to the geometric mean. For n numbers, (x₁ + x₂ + ... + xₙ)/n ≥ (x₁x₂...xₙ)^(1/n). Equality holds when all numbers are equal. This is fundamental for proving many inequalities and optimization problems.

doc_meta.statement: For non-negative real numbers x₁, x₂, ..., xₙ: (x₁ + x₂ + ... + xₙ)/n ≥ (x₁x₂...xₙ)^(1/n). Equality holds iff x₁ = x₂ = ... = xₙ.
doc_meta.proof_sketch: Proof by induction or using convexity of ln(x). For n=2: (x+y)/2 ≥ √(xy) follows from (√x - √y)² ≥ 0.
doc_meta.strategy: Use when product appears in inequality. Normalize sums or use weighted version for coefficients.

examples.solution: By AM-GM: a+b ≥ 2√(ab), b+c ≥ 2√(bc), c+a ≥ 2√(ca). Multiply all inequalities.

documents.title: Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality
documents.text: The Cauchy-Schwarz inequality bounds the dot product of two vectors. In elementary form: (∑aᵢbᵢ)² ≤ (∑aᵢ²)(∑bᵢ²). Engel form (Titu's Lemma): ∑(aᵢ²/bᵢ) ≥ (∑aᵢ)²/∑bᵢ for positive bᵢ.

doc_meta.proof_sketch: Consider discriminant of quadratic ∑(aᵢx + bᵢ)² ≥ 0, or use vector projection.
doc_meta.strategy: Use when sums of squares appear. Engel form useful for fraction sums.

documents.title: Matrix Determinants and Properties
documents.text: The determinant is a scalar value that can be computed from a square matrix. It provides important information about the matrix, including invertibility and volume scaling factor.

doc_meta.statement: For 2×2: det([[a,b],[c,d]]) = ad - bc. For 3×3: use Sarrus rule or cofactor expansion.
doc_meta.proof_sketch: Defined by permutation formula or recursively via cofactor expansion.
doc_meta.strategy: Use for checking invertibility (det ≠ 0), solving systems (Cramer's rule), finding eigenvalues.

documents.title: Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
documents.text: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors characterize linear transformations. An eigenvector only gets scaled when the transformation is applied, not rotated.

doc_meta.statement: For square matrix A, λ is eigenvalue and v is eigenvector if Av = λv with v ≠ 0.
doc_meta.proof_sketch: Solve characteristic equation det(A - λI) = 0 for λ, then solve (A - λI)v = 0 for v.
doc_meta.strategy: 1) Find characteristic polynomial 2) Solve for eigenvalues 3) For each λ, find null space of (A - λI)

documents.title: Gaussian Elimination and Row Reduction
documents.text: Gaussian elimination systematically transforms a matrix to row-echelon form using elementary row operations to solve linear systems.

doc_meta.statement: Three elementary row operations: 1) Swap rows 2) Multiply row by non-zero scalar 3) Add multiple of one row to another
doc_meta.proof_sketch: Each operation preserves solution set of linear system.
doc_meta.strategy: 1) Get leading 1 in first row 2) Eliminate below 3) Repeat for subsequent rows 4) Back substitute

examples.prompt: Solve using Gaussian elimination: 3x + 2y = 8, x - y = 1

documents.title: Subspaces and Vector Spaces
documents.text: A subspace is a subset of a vector space that is itself a vector space under the same operations. Must be closed under addition and scalar multiplication.

doc_meta.statement: Subset W ⊆ V is subspace iff: 1) 0 ∈ W 2) Closed under addition 3) Closed under scalar multiplication
doc_meta.proof_sketch: Verify three conditions directly from definitions.
doc_meta.strategy: Check zero vector, then closure under both operations. For solution sets, verify homogeneous equations.

examples.prompt: Prove 3×3 diagonal matrices form subspace of all 3×3 matrices
examples.solution: 1) Zero matrix is diagonal ✓ 2) Sum of diagonals is diagonal ✓ 3) Scalar multiple of diagonal is diagonal ✓

documents.title: Vieta's Formulas for Polynomial Roots
documents.text: Vieta's formulas relate polynomial coefficients to sums and products of roots. Essential for symmetric polynomial problems.

doc_meta.statement: For P(x)=xⁿ + aₙ₋₁xⁿ⁻¹ + ... + a₀ with roots r₁,...,rₙ: ∑rᵢ = -aₙ₋₁, ∑rᵢrⱼ = aₙ₋₂, ..., r₁r₂...rₙ = (-1)ⁿa₀
doc_meta.proof_sketch: Compare coefficients in expanded form P(x) = (x-r₁)...(x-rₙ)
doc_meta.strategy: Use to express symmetric functions of roots in terms of coefficients.

examples.prompt: If α,β,γ roots of x³-2x²+3x-4=0, find αβ+βγ+γα
key_steps: Identify coefficient for sum of pairwise products

documents.title: Cauchy's Functional Equation
documents.text: The fundamental functional equation f(x+y) = f(x) + f(y). Solutions depend on domain and additional conditions.

doc_meta.statement: Over reals with continuity: f(x) = cx. Over rationals: f(x) = cx. Without regularity: pathological solutions exist.
doc_meta.proof_sketch: Show f(q) = cq for rational q, extend to reals via continuity/density.
doc_meta.strategy: Plug special values (0,1), prove f(qx)=qf(x) for rational q, look for linear solutions.

examples.prompt: Find all continuous f:ℝ→ℝ satisfying f(x+y)=f(x)+f(y)
examples.solution: f(0)=0, f(n)=nf(1), f(1/n)=f(1)/n, f(m/n)=mf(1)/n, by continuity f(x)=xf(1)

documents.title: Linear Transformations and Matrix Representations
documents.text: Linear transformations preserve vector space operations. Every linear transformation between finite-dimensional spaces can be represented by a matrix.

doc_meta.statement: T: V → W is linear if T(u+v) = T(u) + T(v) and T(cv) = cT(v) for all vectors u,v and scalars c
doc_meta.proof_sketch: Matrix representation obtained by applying T to basis vectors and expressing results in target basis.
doc_meta.strategy: To find matrix: apply T to each basis vector, write results as columns in target basis coordinates

examples.prompt: Find matrix for T(x,y,z) = (x+y, y+z, z+x)

documents.title: Matrix Inverses and Invertibility
documents.text: A square matrix is invertible if there exists a matrix that multiplies with it to give the identity. Equivalent to having non-zero determinant.

doc_meta.statement: A is invertible iff det(A) ≠ 0 iff columns are linearly independent iff A has full rank
doc_meta.proof_sketch: Use adjugate formula A⁻¹ = adj(A)/det(A) or show existence via Gaussian elimination
doc_meta.strategy: Check det ≠ 0. Find inverse via: 1) Gaussian elimination 2) Adjugate formula 3) Formula for 2×2

documents.title: Basis and Dimension
documents.text: A basis is a linearly independent spanning set. The number of basis vectors is the dimension of the space.

doc_meta.statement: B vectors form basis for V if: 1) B spans V 2) B is linearly independent. Dimension = |B|
doc_meta.proof_sketch: All bases have same size by replacement theorem.
doc_meta.strategy: To find basis: 1) Find spanning set 2) Remove dependent vectors until independent

examples.prompt: Find basis for solution space of x + 2y - z = 0
examples.solution: z = x + 2y, so vectors: [1,0,1]ᵀ, [0,1,2]ᵀ. These are independent and span solution space

documents.title: Polynomial Factorization and Roots
documents.text: Factorization breaks polynomials into simpler factors. Closely related to finding roots of polynomials.

doc_meta.statement: Factor Theorem: (x-a) is factor iff P(a)=0. Remainder Theorem: P(a) is remainder when dividing by (x-a)
doc_meta.strategy: Use Rational Root Theorem to test possible roots, then synthetic division to factor

documents.title: Matrix Rank and Nullity
documents.text: Rank measures the dimension of the column space (image). Nullity measures the dimension of the null space (kernel).

doc_meta.statement: Rank-Nullity Theorem: rank(A) + nullity(A) = number of columns of A
doc_meta.proof_sketch: Extend basis of null space to basis of domain space.
doc_meta.strategy: Find rank via: 1) Row reduction to count pivots 2) Dimension of column space. Nullity = n - rank

examples.solution: Row reduce: rows 2 and 3 become dependent. Rank = 2 (2 pivots), nullity = 3-2=1

documents.title: Schur's Inequality
documents.text: Schur's inequality is a fundamental symmetric inequality for three variables, useful for Olympiad problems.

doc_meta.statement: For a,b,c ≥ 0 and real r: aʳ(a-b)(a-c) + bʳ(b-c)(b-a) + cʳ(c-a)(c-b) ≥ 0. Common cases: r=1 and r=2
doc_meta.proof_sketch: By symmetry, assume a ≥ b ≥ c. Rearrangement or SOS method.
doc_meta.strategy: Use when cubic terms appear. Often combined with AM-GM or Cauchy-Schwarz

examples.solution: This is Schur's inequality with r=1

documents.title: Matrix Diagonalization
documents.text: A matrix is diagonalizable if it can be written as PDP⁻¹ where D is diagonal. Equivalent to having basis of eigenvectors.

doc_meta.statement: A is diagonalizable iff it has n linearly independent eigenvectors (geometric multiplicity = algebraic multiplicity for each eigenvalue)
doc_meta.proof_sketch: P has eigenvectors as columns, D has eigenvalues on diagonal.
doc_meta.strategy: 1) Find eigenvalues 2) Find n independent eigenvectors 3) Form P from eigenvectors, D from eigenvalues
